fields.description:
Participants:  	 Chris Ueland and Michael Knighten [Atlassian]

Have a space (possibly a new Portal View) which creates a tab at the top of the portal homepage for a team based confluence - maybe for team contact info, company news, a "production push log", etc.

Michael Knighten [Atlassian] - 04/Apr/08 06:14 PM
Hi Chris,

Good idea. We have on the roadmap adding a 'Project Summary' tab to the JIRA project dashboard. This tab would contain wiki content, as well as configurable links for downloads, etc. Additionally, we've got planned to add a 'Team' tab which contains a listing of team members w/ picture & contact info. Sounds kind of like what you have in mind here. If you have a few minutes, would you mind expanding on your ideas? I'd like to get a better understanding of what you're hoping to see, and we can take these into account as we develop the specs.

Michael
fields.summary: Have a Confluence area for the Team separate from the Project wikis

fields.description:
From David Soul:

A customer has emailed us to say that they're interested in having hosted Studio connect to respositories that are hosted in-house. Kevin Pierce (kpierce@vendasta.com) says:

> The only tool we forsee truely needing to handled ourselves inhouse is
> svn, since we use this heavily for all types of activity and require
> real network connectivity.

Just for your consideration.

Customer comment:

Gus Heck - 18/Mar/08 05:48 PM
Not having admin access to one's repository gives me the willies. If anything gets messed up (such as accidental check in of sensitive information that must be removed) the inability to shut down access, dump/filter/etc is a serious problem (and yes I've had to do that :-( ). However, if one could connect your services with a repository that I can manage freely. Also, having my code live elsewhere and only being able to get a backup via a service ticket is an issue. Are you prepared for users that file weekly tickets for backups? And the faq seems to indicate that none of the backups you do can be re-loaded, so if something goes wrong the only option is to quit using Jira studio to fix the problem? what is the use of a backup that can't be loaded?

Don't get me wrong, I love the idea that I one could potentially get going on Jira/confluece/fisheye/crucible for only $50/month. That's an awesome concept, but having to put my subversion there is something I view as an additional cost. What would be a benefit would be a service to automatically replicate or back up my subversion repository. Perhaps you could have a mode where a regular polling for new versions on an external server is done and then when new versions are detected, a robot client updates to each version successively and checks in the changes to the repository at Atlassian one by one.

In pseudo code:

while(accountIsPaidUp())
  if(newVersionsFound())
    foreach(getNewVersionList() as v )
      updateCheckoutSpaceToVersion(v)
      copyNonSubversionFilesToCheckinSpace()
      Options opts = determineCheckInOptions() // this is possibly difficult :)
      commitCheckinSpace(options)

That would allow you to have all the integration with your tools operating locally. There's probably a bit more with some of the other funky bits of subversion like locks, but I'll leave that as an exercise for the folks who're getting paid for this :) Anyway, just a thought for you because I definately like where you are going, but I'm not sure I could follow yet.

I would expect that an account set up to use external repositories would NOT be allowed to make any changes to the atlassian copy of the repository directly (only via the mirroring process).
fields.summary: Support external Subversion repositories

1) Create a Wiki page call "The Spec"
2) Do an SVN commit
3) include "DEMO-2 \[The Spec\]" in the commit log
4) Go to the DEMO-2 issues, and select the "Source" tab

Expected results:
\[The Spec\] will have been converted into a link to a Wiki page

Actual results:
The text \[The Spec\] is shown, and is not a link.

For an example, see http://demo.jira.com/browse/DEMO-2

fields.description:
Currently, we have a bunch of config files that get copied into the existing apps. This is highly dangerous because if the file in the original app changes, we have no way of knowing we are clobbering that change.

Some possible fixes:

1. Use patch (or some variant) so that our changes are applied to the existing file, and the build will fail if the patch can not be applied successfully
2. Add a checksum to the copy, so that if the stored checksum of the file we are overwriting changes, the build will fail.
fields.summary: Make file-override process more robust against original file modification

The Delete Project confirmation page should also list a message notifying the user that all Crucible information related to the project has been deleted.

From our point of view, FishEye and Crucible are seen as one application so when FishEye is deleted then the Crucible data is deleted too. However, it may not be obvious to the end user, who may wonder what happened to the Crucible information related to the project that was just deleted.
fields.summary: Delete Project confirmation page should inform user that Crucible data has also been deleted

Afterwards I went to Confluence. It had apparently not picked up the change (I needed 'space admin' permissions granted only to 'administrators'). In the sysadmin user's Confluence profile, the 'administrator' group is *not* listed:

!sysadmin_viewprofile.png!

However in the Confluence user browser, the group is listed:

!sysadmin_user.png!

fields.summary: When in Crucible, a AJAX timeout destroys the Crucible page

fields.description:
see https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JST-88

Trying to remove an user fails, then appears to have worked later. Pull in the Crowd guys on this, as I'm certain its a Crowd caching issue.

*From the ticket:*
We are paying for a 5 user license for Jira Studio. I've created 2 users, both of whom will have admin rights. But the Studio Administration page says that we only have two more users left to assign, and offers to upgrade.

We do not need a user called "admin" and have exactly 5 users whom we need to assign access to Jira Studio. When I try to delete this generic admin user (from my username of stu, which has administration rights) I get the following message:

"Exception trying to remove user: com.opensymphony.user.ImmutableException: Credentials provider failed to remove user"

It's fine if atlassian would like this user to be there for their purposes, but not if it counts against the user quota we're paying for. If we're paying per user, and have 5 users to assign, it is not acceptable that in reality we have only 4. This will be a showstopper for us, so I look forward to your response.

*Then:*
Argh! Now the admin user is gone. It's what I wanted, but it's confusing to me why I got an error message saying the remove failed (which is why I submitted the ticket) and when I re-login it is gone. Np, I'm happy with the outcome. A bit odd though.

Excited about exploring Jira Studio. We've been waiting for this to go live for a while, and it looks like a fantastic product.
fields.summary: delete user fails - works later (crowd caching)

fields.description:
Note: I don't think this is a big one for Studio, because as far as I can see it affects only the Studio Administration pages, which are:
(a) Accessible to Atlassian staff only ( ? ) and
(b) not much affected by the changes in Confluence 2.8.

But I'll leave it up to the Studio guys to assess :)

We need to redirect any links which currently point from the Confluence application into the DOC space on CAC, so that they will point to the CONF27 space instead.

Reason: On Tuesday 25 March, we will declare the DOC space to be a beta for Confluence 2.8. From that date, the documentation in that space will begin to reflect Confluence 2.8 rather than 2.7. But JIRA Studio uses version 2.7.

Is it possible to implement a global redirect from anything beginning with 
{code}
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC
{code}
to point to this instead:
{code}
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONF27
{code}

There are online help links in the Confluence application. As far as Studio is concerned, I think there are only the ones in the Wiki Admin pages, such as:
* An in-text hyperlink in the 'Help Tips' on the 'Global Templates' page --- action =  https://studio.atlassian.com/wiki/pages/templates/listpagetemplates.action. Currently points to http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Global+Templates

Note: Space CONF27 is currently hidden from public view, but will be revealed on Tuesday 25 March.
fields.summary: Redirect all online help links in Confluence application to point to CONF27 space
